newsitem.title: ZAMBIA: ZAMBIA TARGETS 5.5 PERCENT GDP GROWTH IN 1997.
newsitem.headline: ZAMBIA TARGETS 5.5 PERCENT GDP GROWTH IN 1997.

text.p: The Zambian government said on Friday it would seek a 5.5 percent growth in real Gross Domestic Product (GDP) in 1997, after a 6.4 percent growth in 1996.
"The main thrust of this year's economic policy is a 5.5 percent growth in real GDP, while maintaining macro-economic stability," finance minister Ronald Penza said in his 1997 budget speech.
Penza said he expected inflation to drop to 15 percent by the end of the year from 35 percent recorded at the end of 1996.
"Furthermore, government spending will be focused on those areas that support growth. In this regard, it will be necessary to run an overall budget surplus of about one percent of GDP," he said.
Government spending would be focused on the road rehabilitation programme, which would be allocated 30 billion kwacha ($22.7 million), agriculture and to the provision of social services.
"To maintain macro-economic stablity and to achieve the inflation target, it will be important to maintain a tight fiscal and monetary stance," Penza said.
He said broad money growth would have to be kept within the expected real GDP growth and the inflation target.
Penza said the public sector reform programme, which was suspended last year for lack of finances, would be speeded up this year to reduce the government's wage bill.
He said the government would encourage public servants to opt for retirement.

He said the 6.4 percent growth registered in 1996 came from agriculture (28.7 percent), mining (12.2 percent), manufacturing (2.5 percent), tourism (17.7 percent) commerce and trade (13 percent) and non-traditional exports (23 percent).
